Regeneration | Birnbaum Lab                                   Regeneration            The Trajectory of Regenerating Cells   The root grows continuously by the replenishment of cells within and around the Quiescent Center (QC), which is marked by the green fluorescent protein on the left. New cells replenish the files of cells in the shootward direction and also in the opposite direction to form a root cap. The root cap consists of columella cells, which help sense gravity, and lateral root cap cells. The highly organized structure and optical clarity of the root permits live imaging of regeneration at high resolution. Remarkably, we can cut away the self-replenishing cells (stem cells) and the root will regenerate, re-specifying the columella, the QC, the lateral root cap and other cells (pictured below). The root can even regenerate these cells in mutants that lack stem cell activity. We are pursuing several questions in this system:   • What cells contribute to the newly regenerated root tip?  • What cues re-initiate patterning and establish new tissue borders and organ shape?  • How do developmental programs respond to injury signals?  • What signals support the stem cell behavior?   We have a high-resolution regeneration imaging system in which we can track regenerating roots at cellular resolution for several days. We have also developed single-cell RNA-Seq techniques for single regenerating cells that permit us to ask about their molecular trajectory during regeneration. In addition, we use genetics to test our models about re-organization in the root.    Propidium Iodide (cell wall)    PET111- GFP (columella), Propidium Iodide (cell wall)    pWOX5:WOX5- GFP (QC), Propidium Iodide (cell wall)

Regeneration | Birnbaum Lab                                   Regeneration            The Trajectory of Regenerating Cells   The root grows continuously by the replenishment of cells within and around the Quiescent Center (QC), which is marked by the green fluorescent protein on the left. New cells replenish the files of cells in the shootward direction and also in the opposite direction to form a root cap. The root cap consists of columella cells, which help sense gravity, and lateral root cap cells. The highly organized structure and optical clarity of the root permits live imaging of regeneration at high resolution. Remarkably, we can cut away the self-replenishing cells (stem cells) and the root will regenerate, re-specifying the columella, the QC, the lateral root cap and other cells (pictured below). The root can even regenerate these cells in mutants that lack stem cell activity. We are pursuing several questions in this system:   • What cells contribute to the newly regenerated root tip?  • What cues re-initiate patterning and establish new tissue borders and organ shape?  • How do developmental programs respond to injury signals?  • What signals support the stem cell behavior?   We have a high-resolution regeneration imaging system in which we can track regenerating roots at cellular resolution for several days. We have also developed single-cell RNA-Seq techniques for single regenerating cells that permit us to ask about their molecular trajectory during regeneration. In addition, we use genetics to test our models about re-organization in the root. Preparing for NYU | New Student Center | New York University                                              Navigation       College of Arts and Science                 About Arts and Science | Departments and Programs | The Faculty                       Home > Preparing for NYU         Preparing for NYU     Before Virtual Advising and Registration (May and June):       Submit your confirmation deposit to NYU Admissions.    Activate your NYU email account. Form any internet-connected computer visit start.nyu.edu to get started. Enter your NYU NetId and then follow the instructions.    Complete the Virtual Advising and Registration requirements. You will receive email communications from the CCP Leadership Team to your NYU email account about what you need to do starting at the beginning of May, as long as you have submitted your deposit to NYU Admissions. Before CAS Orientation (End of August):       Continue checking your NYU email, you will receive a list of CAS Orientation events the first week of August.    Start familiarizing yourself with the NYU campus and its many resources, as well as New York City .    Apply for your NYU ID Card .    Sign up for NYU Welcome Week events starting mid-August.    Complete the AlcoholEdu® for College program. All undergraduate first-year students are required to complete this two part program . You will receive more information from NYU’s Student Health Center during August.    Pay tuition bill. More information can be found about deadlines for payment through the NYU Bursar Office .    Follow-up with the Office of Undergraduate Admissions to confirm that they have received high school transcripts and any other necessary paperwork. Sign up for Student Health Insurance (optional).    Pay Housing Deposit. More information can be found through the Residential Life and Housing Services website.    Purchase textbooks for fall classes at the NYU Bookstore.    Complete and confirm that the Student Health Center has received your necessary immunization forms (verifying your vaccination history) before the start of classes.
